page.lettertext:
fol.277r
1592 21 August To M
r
Bodly
S
r
. This matter that hath hounge in Balance so longe for
lack of a full Conclusion, is nowe heare by hir
Ma
tie
absolutelie
resolved that hir nombers aforetime limited for
France
, shall presently
w
th
all the speed that maie be, be drawen to the Sea side, and shipped
wherin yow may
ceave, that se
y
g
e
2 band
in re
d
es to
have bene dra
w
fr
o
ostend shall remayne
ther ar now to c
o
e
but 16 band
to passe to
Caen
, for execuc
o
n whereof yowe shall hearew
th
receive
hir Ma
ties
l
re
s, to the Contentes whereof I doe referre yowe, and if
Mons
r
Caron
be c
u
m thither, yowe shall doe well to move him to
further the same to be w
th
the good wills of the
States
, as he
hath promised to further the same knowinge hir Ma
ties
ernest determi-
nac
o
n thearein./ Howe
Buzenval
hath delt anie waies for
the
K.
theare, of late I have not herd from yowe. The
Commissarie
of Musters for
Berghen
hath diligentlie sent hither
his Bookes of the Musters of the Bandes that are appointed to goe
into Fraunce, w
ch
are more perfectlie filled w
th
their nombers
than I did looke for, But of the state of the nombers that
s
rved
under
S
r
Francis Veere
, I cowld as yet heare noe report made
thence, althowgh yowe knowe
e same was required spetiallye
to the intent that according to the defect
, newe supplies made be
made heare in
England
to fill upp the Bandes when they showld
c
u
m into France./ I praie yowe peruse well the direcc
o
ns that
weare geven yowe the first of Julie by Articles from my
LLs
of
the Counsell, and so deale w
th
S
r
Francis Veere, and
S
r
Thomas Morgan
as the direcc
o
n thearein maie be performed, whereof I doe nowe
forbeare to make anie newe recitall./ At this time wee heare
not what is bec
u
m of
Coverden
, neither whether it be trewe that the
Ennemie hath passed forces over the River / Of that w
ch
yowe latelie
wrote to mee of
Groninghen
, I wishe to heare sum good proceedinge
thearein./ From
Callis
and
Flanders
wee heare common report,
of great preparac
o
n made by Boates, and such other like, w
th
opinion
of sum Attempt intended against
Ostend
, but from Ostend it self, I
can heare noe newes. A little before Mons
r
de Caron were heare
he made grevous complaint of lack of Justice heare for recoverye of
shippes and good
taken from the people of thes Provinc
, and being required
by mee to deliver sum Remonstrance or Catalogue of the perticuler Com-
plaintes, I sent the same to
e Judge of the Admiraltye, whoe sodenlie [by]
my request hath apostilled the same w
th
certaine Awnsweares, thowgh
not so perfectlie delivered as weare fitt in so publicque a Cawse: nev[er]
theles bicause it maie be that Mons
r
de Caron maie theare reiterate his
grefes, I have thowght fitt not to have yowe ignorant of the Complaint
and the manner of
e Awnsweares, thowgh to
e same much maie be ad[ded]
w
th
further leisure the Considerac
o
n wherof I leave to yowe by sending
to yowe the Copie of the same.
From
e Cort at Aldermarston in
Barkeshire this xxj
th
of August.
1592.
Yours allweis assured William Burghley
